editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.p: Lucubratiuncula Poetica De Moribus rite Inſtituendis.
Ubi etiam Decalogus, Precatio Dominica, & Symbolum Apoſtolorum.

In uſum puerorum, ut tenellae ipſorummentes pietatis & virtutis ſapore quamprimum imbuantur, [ Eccl. 12.1.
Memento Creatoris tui, in diebus juventutis tuae.
Horat. Lib. 1. Epiſt. 2.
Quo ſemel eſt imbuta recens ſervabit odorem Testa diu.

lg.l: Inſere quamprimum Pietatis ſemen in ima
Corda, ut eo citius, clara, ſuperna, colas.

Inſtanter
que viam virtutis carpe probatam
Cujus ſunt Comites, gratia, nomen, opes.
Jugiter illicitos inſultus interiores
Cordicitus cunctos corripe, confiicito.

div.p: Edinburgi, Excudebant Haeredes Andreae Anderſon, Regis, Civitatis & Academiae Typographi, Anno Dom. 1700.

div.head: Lucubratiuncula Poetica de Moribus. Apologia pro Verſuum Stylo Plano.

lg.l: NOn Calamiſtratos ſtudeo conflare cothurnos,
Seſquipedalia nec verba tonare placet:
At plano invenies decoratos ſemper amictu
Planiùs ut poſſint, pleniùs atque capi.

lg.head: 1 Foelix ſapientia ſuperna curare.
lg.l: Mi puer hi verſu • ſint altâ mente repôſti
Ut tua tincta fiet mens pietate citò
Is ſapit & foelix, qui ſurſum lumina vertit
Proſequitur viſum, viſaque corde cupit.

lg.head: 2. Baptiſmatis vota reminiſcenda.
lg.l: Eſto memor te olim Sacro Baptiſmate tinctum,
Ac exin vinctum, juſſa Patrare Dei.
Carnis & inſultus mundi Satanaeque doloſas
Perturbare Strophas: hoc opus, hic labor eſt

lg.head: 3 Chriſtianum decet Chriſtum imitari.
lg.l: Diſcipulum Chriſti decet illius icona ferre
Quí numeris cunctis, ſanctus & aequus erat,
Manſuetus, verax, humilis, placabilis uſque,
Innocuus, ſpecie candidus abſque doli.

lg.head: 4. Verbum Dei legendum, & agendum.
lg.l: Biblia Sacra lege aſſiduè, dein lecta reconde
Pectoris in fundo. & mente revolve piâ.
Legis ad exemplar vitae compone tenorem
Notitiam & praxin conſociare ſtude.

lg.head: 5 Dei Cultus publicus frequentandus.
lg.l: Publica Templa pete, & divina oracla paratis
Auribus exaudi, dictaque rite nota:
Mundanos, animique vagos, procul excute motus,
Nam fructum perimunt, hoc age, Numen adeſt.

lg.head: 6. Sabbatum religioſè ſanctificandum.
lg.l: Sabbata Sancta Dei, penitus celebrare memento
Officiis Sacris, mente manuque piâ
Dicta Cave non digna Deo, praxeſque profanas
Deliciae tibi ſint, Biblia, Lauſque, preces.

lg.head: 7. Preces Deo quotidie fundendae.
lg.l: Manè preces effunde Deo quumque Heſperus altè
Emicat, ac omni, ſic age, rite die,
Utque tibi eveniunt geſtae res, eſto paratus
Taliter ore preces, Cordeque ferre novas.

lg.head: 8. Deus in omnibus Laudandus.
lg.l: Pange Deo laudes pangant praecordia, pangant
Summâ quâ arte valent, Muſa, labella, lyra:

Nam quodcunque potes, quod habes, nomen
que decuſque
Paxque, ſalus, & opes, ſunt bona dona Dei.

lg.head: 9. Parentes Honorandi.
lg.l: Moriger eſto piis monitis, Juſſiſque Parentum
Sint in honore tibi, ſin inopes, fer opem,
Pagina ſacra j • bet, Lux connatalis & u • get,
Promittitque Deus multiplicare dies.

lg.head: 10. Nec vanè Jurandum, nec Pejerandum.
lg.l: Nauci ergo vanum, falſo jurare ſceleſtum
Non malè proſcindes No • ina Sacra Dei,
Si praetextu ullo fors perjuraveris, Ʋltor
Puntet ipſe Deus, te miſerum miſere.

lg.head: 11. Nec joco nec ſeriò mentiendum.
lg.l:
Peſſimus eſt
• endax hominum, Satanaeque ſodalis
Veridicique irae meta parata Dei.
Contra quod nôſti ſimulatè, nulla profunde
Verbula, neve Joco, nec graviore tono.

lg.head: 12. Luxuria vitanda.
lg.l: Nectare & Ambroſiâ, quamvis tua menſa referta
Cultrum pone gulae, ne nimium capias,
Ebrius atque Gulo, brutis animantibus aptè
Aequiparandi ſunt, nil niſi farta ſtudent.

lg.head: 13 Obſcaena loquela cavenda.
lg.l: Obſcoenas voces nunquam proferto, ſalubris
Sermo ſit & purus, gratus, & uſque gravis
Foetida dicta aures offendent nempe bonorum,
Et ſunt multigeni jugis origo mali.

lg.head: 14. Veneris fugienda libido.
lg.l: Sit procul à votis veneris ſcabioſa voluptas,
Qui tentat, ſibi fert, vulnera, damna, necem:
Spurcos & rapidos hos mox extingue Calores
Corpore ut in caſto, mens quoque caſta ſiet.

lg.head: 15. Furta fugienda
lg.l: Mandati eſto memor, nunquam furabere, furta
Furibus à ſocus ſaepe retecta patent
Tunc infamis eris, tetro quoque ſtigmate inuſtus,
Forſitan & finis, [riteque] funis erit.

lg.head: 16. Reſipiſcentia indies agenda.
lg.l: Culpas multiplicas omni proh tempore grandes
Queîs coram Domino, foedus es atquereus,
Errorum moerore pio reſipiſce, peracta
Crimina fastidi, & cuncta relinque modo.

lg.head: 17. Conſortium pravorum reſpuendum, proborum eligendum.
lg.l: Sperne ſodalitium pravum, vitiiſque notatos
Reſpue, leproſâ nam ſcabie ferient:
Elige pro ſociis claros virtute, proboſque,
Exin clarus eris, carus & uſque bonis.

lg.head: 18. Amicitia cautè ineunda.
lg.l: In conſcribendis, ne fis incautus, amicis,
Rara avis in terris, certus amicus amans,
Foedus Amicitiae, cum conſultò pepigiſti
Ut quid ſacratum, rite, pièque cole,

lg.head: 19. Nemo convitiís afficiendus.
lg.l: Opprobriis ſocii nunquam pete nomen honeſtum
Livida ne ſcurrae ſit tibi parta nota
Saepe ſit eventu juſto, qui carpere ſannis
Sunt alios ſoliti ac arte perire ſuâ.

lg.head: 20. Tempus labile & irrevocabile.
lg.l: Hora brevis velut umbra vagans agitata per auras
Aufugit, utque levis bullala tacta manu.
At quum exacta ſemel, nunquam revocabilis, ergo
Puncto nunc quod habes, utere rite, probè.

lg.head: 21. Nulla dies ſine linea.
lg.l: Nulla dies pereat ſine linea, inaniter horam
Non unam perdes, hoc age, doctus eris.
Aut nunc, aut nunquam, floret dum firma juventus
Cana dies properat debilitaſque gravis.

lg.head: 22. Doctrina ad omnia utilis.
lg.l: Doctior eſſe ſtude, bene doctus ad omnia promptus,
Qui ſine doctrina eſt, hominis deforme cadaver
Prae ſe fert graphicè, quum moritur nihil eſt.

lg.head: 23. Pietas ad omnia perutilis.
lg.l: Sanctior eſſe frude, ſanctorum libera merces
P • x, honor, alma dies, gloria. palma, Deus.
Qui pietate caret, Stygium trudetur in Orcum
Semper ubi vivunt, morſque, truceſque cruces.

lg.head: 24. Fama vulgi volatilis, non reſpicienda.
lg.l: I d velut Aura levi • laus vulgi, temporis uno
Puncto, altè tollunt, dejiciunt alio,
Rarè judicio certo, rarò ratione
Ducuntur, mens aſt hinc rotat inde vagans.

lg.head: 25. Sint mores omnino probi.
lg.l: Moribus eſto pius, prudens, affabilis, aequus,
Urbanuſque, humilis, ſuavis, & uſque gravis;
Protinus & vigila, ne tu ſis garrulus, audax,
Effrons, moroſus, turbidus, aut tumidus.

lg.head: 26. Vitae infortunia ſunt patienter ferendat
lg.l: Qualiacunque Deo viſum tibi cudere damna,
Sufferto placidè, murmura rauca cave.
Nam ſine divina cura nil accidit unquam,
Laeta dat, & repetit, mittit & Arcta Deus,

lg.head: 27. Virtus vera Nobilitas.
lg.l: Quid ſtrepitas proavos? generis quid ſtemmata Jactas?
Non ſtirps ſola beat, nomen inane nihil,
Nobilis eſſe cupis? virtutis corde capeſſe
Greſſus, ſic Heros inclytus eſſe potes.

lg.head: 28. Terrena vana, Lubrica.
lg.l: Omne quod errantis ſub Lunae fornice conſtat,
Ut fert Luna vices, ſic fluit, & refluit,
Innumeris terrena patent ſubitiſque Perîclis
Proſterni, tragicâ ſtrageque ſaepe cadunt.

lg.head: 29. Coeleſtia ſuper omnia petenda.
lg.l: Poſthabitis mundi tricis, Coeleſtia Arhelans,
Perpetuo nixu, quae ſuper aſtra pete,
Elige Theſaurum Chriſti munimine tutum
Qui nullo perdi Marte, nec Arte poteſt.

lg.head: 30. Memento Mori.
lg.l: Pallida mors properat, facie mucore linita,
Dextra tela tenens, quêis citò Corda ferit,
Non faſces, nec opes, non vis, nec ſana Juventus,
Tutari à mortis falce vorace valent.

div.head: DECALOGƲS.
div.l: 1. UNus ego Deus, ex aequo tua vota preceſque
Miſoli facies, ſpemque fidemque dabis.
2. Non tibi pro libitu confinges Icona vanam
Sacrilegus ſculptum qui colit Arte Deum.
3. Non uſurpabis Domini Sacra Nomina fruſtr.
Zelotypus perdet vindice mente reum.
4. Sabbata ſancta Dei nenitus celebrare memento,
Impia cordicitus, dictaque, facta cave.
5. Sint in honore tibi ſummo, meritoque, parentes,
Ut valeas longâ pace dieque frui.
6. Occides nullum, (caedis vox aethera pulſat)

Ne vel conſilio,
〈…〉
… que manu.
7. Nec voto, nec ocellis, nec moechabere facto
Laſcivus moechus fert ſibi damna citò.
8. In damnum alterius ne quid furabere, ſemper
Rectè fac aliis, ut tibi vis fieri.
9. Non ſocium laedes verbis mendacibus unquam
Nec de cauſa ulla, teſtis iniquus eris.
10. Concupies nunquam illicitè, quod proximus aequo
Jure tenet neu quae maxima, ncc minima.

div.head: ORATIO DOMINICA.
div.l: Omnis ubique colat populus tua Nomina diva:
Adveniat regnumque tuum—Tua tota voluntas
Sicut apud ſuperos, in terris ſic peragatur:
Atque diurnum panem hodie conferre memento:
Noxia cuncta reis ignoſcito crimina nobis:
Prout ſociis noſtris culpaſque remi • timus ultro:
Ne nos inducas unquam in tentamina dura:
Sed nos incolumes ſerva ne quae mala turbent:
Nam tua ſunt ſemper, regnum, vis, laus, honor, Amen.

div.head: Symbolum Apoſtolorum.
div.l: IN Numen credo Genitorem Cunctipotentem
Omnia de nihilo, qui Solâ voce creavit,
Quae tenet haec tellus, vel quae comprendit Olympus:
Credo quoque in Chriſtum meritis qui ſalvat iniquos:
Quem Solùm • olus genuit Pater ille perennis:
Qui conce • tus erat mirè, Spiramine Sancto
A Spirante Deo; natus de ventre ſacrato
Virginis eſt Mariae: paſſus ſub Judice nequam
Pilato: fixuſque cruci manibus ſceleratis
Inter damnatos (ac ſi malus ipſe) latrones:
His crucibus miſere laceratus, deſerit artus
Spiritus, exangue ingenti tunc corpus & altâ
In tumulo curâ poſitum; deſcendit ad uſque
Inferiora loca: atque die poſt funera trino
In domitus domitae rupto religamine mortis
Ad vitam rediit: demumque choris Comitatus
Angelicis, Coelos petiit: ſedemque parentis
Ad dextram caepit, medians pro ſontibus uſque:
Exin venturus zeloſè Judicis aequi
Officio fungi, vivos ergaque ſepultos:
In numen credo proceſſum à patre ſimulque
A Gnato, mirando modo, quem noſtra cerebra
Prêndere non poſſunt, ſpiſſà caligine tecta:
Credo Catholico coetu ſacroque potiri
Chriſtum, qui firmo ſunt illi foedere juncti,
Atque fide fidâ, capiti prout membra ligantur;
Hos credo ſanctos communes reddere nixus
Alternoſque piis votis, & munere cuncto,
Ut bene ſit cunctis: credo Dominumque paratum
Ingratis nobis, culpas ignoſcere gratis:
Credo quodque caro certò poſt fata reſurget:
Denique credo fide firmâ, poſt tempora praeſto
Eſſe aliam vitam, cui nullus terminus: Amen.

div.head: Gratiarum Actio.
div.l: O Deus mi quot mihi non merenti
Large & en gratis bona dona largus
Commodaſti tu quibus uſque vinctus
Sum tuus eſſe:
Ac tibi ſemper famulari, & o ſi
Afforent linguae mihi mille, longè
Et tuas latè ut celebrare poſſim
Riteque laudes:
Gratias ſummas dare corde vellem
Et tuam famam reſonare voce
Dum calor cordis viget, aura vitae
Pulſat & Artus.
Nuncque quas vovi celebrare laudes
Debitas, o mi Pater alme reddo,
Lingua dat, mens dat, lyra datque Pſalmos
Milleque grates.

lg.head: Fortitudo
lg.l: Fortis, qui ſuperat ſe, aegroſq • e libidinis aeſtros
Fortè domat, placidè ſorte fruique poteſt.

lg.head: Juſtitia.
lg.l: Juſtus, qui cunctis ſua rectâ lance rependit
Cum ſibi, tum ſocio, praecipuèque Deo.

lg.head: Temperantia.
lg.l: Sobrius, Affectus rapidos qui temperat ultro,
Ne nimis excedat, veſte, liquore, gulâ.

lg.head: Prudentia.
lg.l: Prudens, ſurgentes qui proſpicit eminus undas,
Tutam Arcamque ſibi providus antè parat.
Mente, manu, labiis: ſophiam, in certa arte Deumque
Diſce, labora, ora: gnaviter, uſque, piis.
Chriſtus Salvator, Genitorem, Animas, Satanamque;
Placat, emit, ſpoliat: ſanguine, morte, manu:
Mundum, carnem, laſcivam, Cacodaemonis hamos:
Deſpice, mortifica, providus uſque cave:
Fida fides, Amor ardens, mens pia, certus Amicus,
Exulat, extinctus, rara avis, Ʋtopiae eſt.

div.head: Corollarium de Chriſti miris, & validis virtutibus.
div.l: CUm Chriſtus digito pulſat praecordia divo,
In ſegmenta citò ferrea clauſtra terit.
Quamvis foeda, caro, Satanas, munduſque repugnent,
Attamen ad ſeſe, corda proterva trahit.
Et quum flammiferam fors deſuper exerit Artem
Suſcitat in flammam cor glaciale ſacram.
Arida corda rigans, perfuſo rore ſuperno
Fructus quam ſapidos perpetuoſque ferunt.
Cimmerias longè tenebras diſpellit, & imam
Irradiat mentem, luce ſupernèſatâ,
Praefractis animis quoque for • es imprimit ictus,
Quêis in mollitiem, ſaxea corda domat.
Mens agitata malis furiis compeſcitur, aegros
Et mulcet ſtimulos, gaudia larga creans.
Denique divinam transformat ad Icona mentis
Affectus; tandem hunc fert ſuper aſtra virum.
